title: Inverse Transition of Correlated Disorder Revealed by Atomic-Resolution Cryogenic Electron Microscopy
content: Disorder in crystalline materials is the combination of periodically positioned atoms and non-repeating variations, such as chemical composition, atomic shift, bonding arrangement and molecule orientation [1]. In reciprocal space, the Bragg pattern still possesses long-range translation periodicity, while the disorder diffracts as diffuse scattering around the Bragg peaks. There sometimes persist local correlations of those non-repeating variations, which endows the diffuse scattering with anisotropy in reciprocal space and is defined as “correlated disorder” [2]. Over the past few decades, correlated disorder has been harnessed to achieve emergent phenomena and advanced functionalities that are inaccessible in well-ordered systems [3, 4]. Therefore, revealing the evolution of correlated disorder under external stimuli is critical for understanding the disorder-related properties.
